scene.matchingInstructions: Match the items on the left to the correct areas on the right.

matches.match: 1. The level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere started to decline around 2000.
2. The level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has shown a steady increase since 1961.
3. No efforts have been made to reduce the level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere between 1961 and 2011.

hotspots.hotspot: This part of the graph notes all of the developing regions for which this bar graph has data.
This is the key for the graph. This details the different types of water access available in these regions (urban and rural).
This part of the graph shows the percentage of the population in these developing regions that have either urban or rural access to safe drinking water.
The title helps to identify the subject of the bar graph.
Comparing the bars will help you identify relationships between the data and will aide in drawing conclusions.

scene.credits: (tr) Lauren Burke/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images, (bkgd) Image Source/Getty Images.

scene.matchingInstructions: Match the items on the left to the correct areas on the right.

matches.match: 1. This part of the graph shows the different types of water access being compared.
2. This part of the graph lists the different regions being compared.
3. This part of the graph gives the percentage of the population.
4. This part of the graph tells you what the graph is about.

scene.instructions: When you are done, check your results by clicking 'Check Answers.'
scene.credits: (tr) Lauren Burke/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images, (bkgd) Image Source/Getty Images.

multiple.question: According to the bar graph, which developing regions have the least amount of rural access to safe drinking water?

answers.answer: Sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America and the Caribbean have the lowest level of rural access.
Sub-Saharan Africa has the lowest level of rural access.
The Middle East and North Africa and South Asia have the lowest level of rural access.
The Middle East and North Africa has the lowest level of rural access.
East Asia and Pacific have the lowest level of rural access.

scene.credits: (tr) Lauren Burke/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images, (bkgd) Image Source/Getty Images.

multiple.question: Compare the data provided for the World to the developing regions listed. Which developing region surpasses the World statistics for both urban and rural access to safe drinking water?

scene.credits: (tr) Lauren Burke/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images, (bkgd) Image Source/Getty Images.

content.header: Percentages and Types of Pesticides used in the United States Yearly

hotspots.hotspot: Read the title to identify the subject.
Study the information presented and the colors and patterns used. Note how these may help you interpret the graph.
Compare the segments to see the relationship of the parts to the whole. The larger the segment, the greater the percentage of the whole.
Study the labels to understand the numerical information presented.

scene.credits: (tr) Lauren Burke/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images, (bkgd) Image Source/Getty Images.

multiple.question: By comparing the size of the segments, what can you determine about the pesticides used in the United States?

answers.answer: The pesticide used most widely in the United Sates on a yearly basis
How many pounds of each pesticide is used
Which industries most widely use these pesticides
What the percentage of pesticide use is for other countries
Which year the data were collected

scene.credits: (tr) Lauren Burke/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images, (bkgd) Image Source/Getty Images.

multiple.question: A graph is a visual representation of data that have been collected.
The x-axis is the horizontal axis on a graph.
Circle graphs are the best choice when trying to show change over time.
Independent variables are graphed on the vertical axis.
A graph's title shows the relationship between the x and y axes.
Graphs all one to draw conclusions, but do not aid in making inferences.
Bar graphs compare the relationship of parts of a whole as a percentage.

scene.credits: (tr) Lauren Burke/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images, (bkgd) Image Source/Getty Images.
